STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 4, 2022
Laura Nye
Hillsdale County DHHS
40 Care Drive
Hillsdale, MI 49242
RE: License #: CP300201172
Hillsdale County DHHS
40 Care Drive
Hillsdale, MI 49242
Dear Ms. Nye:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
3/3/2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the MISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved. For repeat violations,
please identify why the previous CAP was not successful and what
changes will be made to ensure ongoing compliance.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure

DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT

Services

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12306 Application request.
(4) An agency shall document that the licensee has been given
an application for renewal of the license not less than 60
calendar days before the expiration date of the license.
One of three foster home licensing files did not have documentation that an
application was provided at least 60 days prior to the license expiration date.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs (subsections a-j)
One of seven foster care files did not document the required information
(subsections a-j) for changes of placement that occurred on 10/8/21 and 10/25/21.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2/25/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 3/10/2020
3/15/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 5/4/2021
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be completed not
more than 90 calendar days after placement.
One of seven foster care files did not have an initial dental exam completed within
the required time frame.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2/25/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 3/10/2020
3/15/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 5/4/2021
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
4

FOM 801-01 Health Requirements
Page 4-7
(page 4) A dental re-examination shall be obtained at least
every six months unless a greater frequency is indicated.
(page 7) If a young adult age 18 or older refuses to participate in
medical and dental exams, a DHS-1147, Foster Care Youth
Services Refusal, form must be completed. The DHS-1147 is
completed with the youth to provide health care access and
services information to meet the youth’s health needs. Youth
signature is required.
(page 4) One of seven foster care files had a late dental exam. A dental exam
occurred on 7/8/20; the next exam was not until 3/18/21.
(page 7) One of one IL youth files did not have a dental completed as required. The
last dental on record was 2019. The agency reported the youth was provided with
information to complete a dental but chose not to. However, the agency did not
complete the refusal form (DHS-1147) as required by this policy.
FOM 722-08D Parent Agency Treatment Plan
Page 10
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
Five of seven foster care files held PATPs that were not signed within the required
timeframe.
File one: Non-respondent parent signature missing from 6/23/21 and 9/7/21 PATPs,
as the “caregiver”.
File two: 7/9/21 signed by caregiver on 9/16/21. 10/11/21 signed by parent on
12/10/21. 1/5/22 signed by parent on 2/10/221.
File three:7/13/21 signed by parent on 8/15/21 and caregiver on 11/16/21. 10/11/21
signed by caregiver on 12/20/21. 1/6/22 signed by caregiver 2/14/22.
File four: 8/16/21 signed by parent on 9/17/21 and caregiver on 9/21/21. 11/13/21
signed by parent on 12/21/21 and caregiver on 12/21/21.
File five: 8/6/21 signed by youth on 9/15/21.
FOM 801-03 Medical Passport
Page 2-3
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information…
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed parties is
documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and dated
signature page into the Health Profile section.
5

Two of seven foster care files did not have quarterly updated medical passports.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2/25/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 3/10/2020
3/15/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 5/4/2021
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
Page 12
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is used to
capture family demographics, FTM logistical information, needs,
strengths, action steps, safety concerns and the safety plan,
and any recommendations made for the family during the FTM.
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
One of seven foster care files did not have an 1105 report completed for all FTMs.
1105 reports were missing for 10/5/21 and 1/4/22 FTMs.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2/25/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 3/10/2020
3/15/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 5/4/2021
FOM 722-06H Case Contacts
Page 19
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face contacts
listed below in MISACWIS within five business days of the
contact. This includes attempted and missed face-to-face
contacts.
Three of seven foster care files had foster home visit and parenting time contacts
that were not entered within the required timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2/25/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 3/10/2020
3/15/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 5/4/2021
FOM 722-08A Ongoing Case Service Plan
Page 30
The supervisor must review and approve the service plan within
14 calendar days of the report date.
One of seven foster care files (one of twenty-one USPs) was not approved by the
supervisor within the required time frame.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 The agency was reminded to ensure the 3080, 3706 and 4005
recommendations match when a license renewal is submitted.
 PATP signatures- the agency was informed that non-respondent parents
must sign PATPs as the “caregiver”. In addition, it was clarified that PATP
6

signatures are required within 30 days of the report date, not the report
approval date.
 The agency reported difficulty scheduling medical/dental exams due to
COVID. Staff were encouraged to remind the foster parents that follow-up
appointments should be scheduled before leaving a medical/dental
appointment, to ensure timely scheduling.
 The agency reported a youth that attended a dental appointment but was
unable to finish the appointment due to behavioral issues. A plan was
developed for sedation dentistry at the next appointment. The agency was
advised to ensure thorough documentation is uploaded to support this
incident which resulted in a late dental exam.
 The agency reported difficulty obtaining immunization records for a youth that
previously lived out of state. The agency attempted to contact the health
department of the other state, as well as the youth’s former school. The
agency was advised to document all attempts to obtain the document.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not require consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one incident of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
A special evaluation was initiated on 4/21/21 due to an allegation that a child was
sexually assaulted by a known sex offender, residing in the home of the licensee’s
substitute caregiver. The investigation determined a violation of Rule 201(j) Foster
Parent Qualifications, as the foster parents were aware a sex offender resided in the
home. The DHHS investigation also determine the foster parents failed to provide
the child with proper supervision and protection. The agency recommended
revocation of the license on 7/9/2021. In follow-up on 2/17/22 with the DCWL
Disciplinary Action Unit, it was reported the revocation packet was pending approval
by the Director. A review of documents associated with this report found that the
agency completed a thorough investigation and made a recommendation consistent
with their findings.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
A special evaluation was initiated on 9/9/21 due to allegations the foster parent used
soap in a child’s mouth as punishment and used a belt to spank biological/adopted
children in the home. The Special evaluation concluded on 10/1/21 with findings of
violation for Rule 404(3) behavior management. A safety plan was developed which
included an agreement to refrain from spanking biological/adopted children in the
home while under a borrowed bed agreement with a private agency. The foster
parents also agreed to discontinue use of threatening language or intimidation, and
discontinue threats of soap or other objects as discipline. The agreement indicated
the licensee would use positive reinforcement, participate in youth’s trauma therapy,
follow therapy recommendations, and notify the agency of any incidents. A CAP was
7

signed on 11/15/21 in which the family agreed to the safety plan, reviewed policy,
completed training regarding alternate discipline methods, and provided the agency
with a written summary of what was learned during training. The CAP was
completed on 12/15/21. There are no additional concerns about the home at this
time. The investigation and accompanying documents were reviewed and found to
follow licensing rules.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The CAP, approved 5/4/21, was a result of the 3/15/21 interim review. During the
2021 review, nineteen violations were found. During this 2022 review, the agency
decreased the areas of non-compliance and had nine violations, five of which were
repeats. Although there were repeat violations, each occurrence had decreased
from the prior review. The agency reported several areas of successful CAP
implementation, which is evident by the significant improvement in many areas that
were previously cited.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed and discussed with the agency.
The agency reported that staff have adjusted to a hybrid schedule of in-person and
remote working. The agency reported having some brief staff shortages during the
past year. However, they are now fully staffed and foster care workers have
completed required training. The agency indicated the prior CAP has been
implemented and appears to be going well in many areas. However, there are still
some challenges in regard to timely signatures. Supervisors have developed a
tracking system, which has been helpful in making staff aware of upcoming due
dates. This system has helped staff with planning at a glance when they have
several timeframes to monitor. In addition, staff have focused on compliance with
independent living and placement/replacement documents, as these were areas that
were cited in the past two years. The agency reported using new tools that have
helped in these areas.
Interviews
One foster care and one licensing staff were interviewed. Both staff reported being
with the agency for several years. Both staff stated the environment is positive,
helpful, and they get along well with co-workers. The two staff have different
supervisors, but both reported their supervisors were supportive and helpful. Neither
staff had any concerns or suggestions for improvements at the agency.
VII. ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules, MISEP requirements, or policy. Upon receipt of an
8

acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
________________March 4, 2022________________
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
March 4, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
